---
title: Cultural heritage management and local development in a South Sámi and Norse
  mountainous borderland
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-LXYY8QXU" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Skjeggedal, T., &#38; Overvåg, K. (2017). Cultural heritage management and local development in a South Sámi and Norse mountainous borderland. <i>Norsk Geografisk Tidsskrift - Norwegian Journal of Geography</i>, <i>71</i>(1), 30–45. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1080/00291951.2017.1290674">https://doi.org/10.1080/00291951.2017.1290674</a></div> </div>

</article>
<div id="csl-bib-meta-LXYY8QXU" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-LXYY8QXU" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Skjeggedal and Overvåg examined how cultural heritage management can support local development in two mountain municipalities in southeast Norway. They found that the management of South Sámi and Norse cultural history is highly fragmented, with responsibilities divided among counties and the Sámi Parliament, leaving municipalities without legal duties. This fragmentation leads to neglect, especially of Sámi heritage. The authors suggest that instead of focusing on attracting new residents, local development should prioritize strengthening the community's knowledge, identity, and sense of place through cultural heritage. This approach could help residents feel more connected to their history and environment, fostering a stronger community. Their study involved analyzing planning documents and interviewing various stakeholders involved in cultural heritage, land use, industrial development, and reindeer husbandry.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-LXYY8QXU" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Cultural Heritage, South Sámi, Norse History, Local Development, Municipal Planning, Reindeer Husbandry
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-LXYY8QXU" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    The article discusses how municipal planning and management can enable South Sámi and Norse cultural history to contribute to local development in two sparsely populated mountain municipalities in south-east Norway. The authors’ methods comprised document studies of relevant planning documents and treatment of single cases, and interviews with actors at different levels, who were responsible for cultural heritage, land use planning, industrial development and reindeer husbandry. The findings revealed that the organization of cultural heritage management was extremely fragmented in terms of responsibilities, activities and localization. Responsibility for managing Norse and Sámi cultural heritage is divided between counties and the Sámi Parliament, and the municipalities have no legal responsibilities. This fragmentation contributes to the neglect and marginalization of cultural heritage management in general, and especially the management of Sámi cultural heritage. The discourse of attractiveness based on competing for in-migration from other municipalities holds a hegemonic position in both municipal master planning and regional planning. The authors conclude that a different approach based on local community development, namely the residential place, should be prioritized, whereby cultural heritage is used to strengthen the inhabitants’ knowledge, identity and ‘sense of place’.
  </article>
